ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: to think critically and abstractly  about concrete issues that are currently imaginary but inevitable
The topic was thought experiments, so the ideas are pretty broad, to say the least.

Skills: analytical essays in philosophical and literary style. 
Insights: interesting readings in speculative fiction and science fiction

This was the first philosophy class and the first seminar I took at Yale, and I think it gave me a really great introduction to both. I learned a lot about synthesizing my knowledge across fields and about writing in a philosophical way. Each student in the class brought unique knowledge and insights that made the entire experience extremely valuable and educational.
analyzing philosophical texts
I learned how to apply philosophical arguments to modern-day conundrums.

Every class involved close readings of texts, interesting them and evaluating the merits of their ideas and arguments. The class (through Grimstad and other students) was supportive of wacky, unconventional and difficult ideas and theories about questions of the mind/body, human/non-human.

I developed my ability to think about the humanities and sciences in conjunction, and recognize the elements of each in the other. I also really worked on my ability to pick out the detailed and emotional ways that scientific and technological ideas are evoked in literature.
This course introduced me to a ton of thought experiments and challenged my skills in analyzing/applying them to "real" life.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths are how student led the seminars are. Weaknesses are we could've gone a bit deeper into each topic outside our readings; more guidance from the professor in elaborate directions might be good. love him though!

Strengths: Great discussions, great material--everything about the seminar was good.

Weaknesses: Class size was probably a little too big. Sometimes I felt that I just had to say something even though it was not particularly relevant to the discussion at hand.

The syllabus is so incredibly engaging  there is a diverse range of media types, so you get to analyze many different things! I also really enjoyed the freedom Professor Grimstad gave us on the papers. It allowed you to explore what you were interested in, rather than confining you to one topic.

Strengths: Really cool readings, very reasonable workload, and the chance to really get engaged in discussions. Lots of feedback on essays. 
Weaknesses: If you're not part of the "main stream" of discussion, it can feel difficult to feel involved or invested. Essay feedback isn't always helpful for generally improving at writing, focuses more on the specific material discussed in the essay.

I loved the curriculum and teaching style of this class. The professor was extremely engaged and accessible. The only thing that could have made the class even better might have been to establish guidelines for participation during class early in the semester to facilitate a more natural flow of conversation. I also think the class would have benefited by being a little bit smaller, but I did enjoy everything that each student contributed.
I enjoyed the essays and Professor Grimstad provided a lot of good support with the writing process.

the strengths are Grimstad, the readings which were always fantastic - when I usually skip readings for class I'm thankful when the class is over and I don't have to pretend to know whats going on, but I always would regret not doing the readings for thought experiments because the discussion would always be lively and thought-provoking.

I think that the core strength of the course was the material that we read and watched. I found the various books, short stories, essays, and films that we explored to be very fascinating and interrelated. The overall thematic flow of the course also made sense, and I appreciated the freedom we had with the topics of our essays. I would say that one thing that could be improved could be finding a way to make some of the contributions to the discussion more succinct, but overall, the class dynamic was great, and the discussion really illuminated new ideas for me.
The discussions were ALWAYS interesting. I looked forward to this class no matter what the topic was.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! it's been one of my favorite classes

Yes, if they are interested in the material. It is a nice blend of literature and philosophy, and you get to see how the two are related. I found most of the readings to be super interesting as well, so you should look at the syllabus beforehand.

Yes! The content is so engaging and Professor Grimstad always makes you feel as if your points are valuable. It is such a great seminar environment  I was never nervous or embarrassed to talk, as I have been in other classes.

You should definitely consider shopping if you like the syllabus. After that, it depends very largely on whether you 'vibe' with the first few discussions. This is more important than you might think.
I would absolutely recommend this class, especially to students who enjoy both STEM and the humanities; I found it an excellent blend of the two.
Yes absolutely! The readings and discussions were so interesting!

Absolutely. One of my favorite classes I have ever had the opportunity to take. Seminars were consistently dynamic, engaging and fascinating. The syllabus materials selected were diverse and each enriched each other.
Yes! This course would be wonderful for anyone interested in the intersection of thought experiments, philosophy and sci-fi.

I could not recommend this class enough. Every class was so engaging. If you're interested in the philosophical side of sci-fi and the literary side of philosophy this class is going to be one of your favorites.
Yes, definitely! It was really fascinating, and I thoroughly enjoyed both reading and writing for the course.

Yes yes yes! You will not regret taking this course no matter what kind of academic background you have. Grimstad is an amazing professor and the syllabus is so interesting. You certainly won't get bored in this class.
